title: IMAP set-up: Can't receive mail
content:
One of my emails in Thunderbird stopped receiving mail. I checked the Profile directory and the INBOX file is gone. I tried copying an INBOX from another email and rebuilding the msf to no avail. Am I completely hosed (no, no backup, but at this point, I really don't care)? I just want to get the emails that are still on the server. I can send emails without a problem. All three emails (all IMAP) I access through Thunderbird are set up the same.

Where do I start? Build is 102.11.0 and I lost the INBOX shortly after the upgrade.
creator: cbelluccix

title: Thunderbird short-term lock-ups
content:
Hi everyone... can you give me some ideas of what kinds of things I should be looking for that might be causing frequent "lockups" in Tbird? I see it only when I'm trying to get something done, obviously, like composing an email or replying to one, for the most part, but also when trying to work my way up the new emails (I generally read them from oldest to newest.) I'll hit delete, and nothing happens, and there's no response to mouse or keyboard input. Most often, it just stops responding while I'm typing. I'm a touch-typist, and when I look up to check for errors, the thing is frozen at a line previous, then it suddenly fills in what I typed while it wasn't responding.

I'm running version 102.10.0, and Linux Mint 21.1 as my O.S. I know there's a .json file that would give a lot of info about Tbird, but I don't know which one it is... let me know and I'll post it, if it's needed.

I just migrated from Windows 10 to Linux exclusively... had it with Windows nonsense. Tbird ran flawlessly at first, but the lockup issue is happening more frequently with time/use.

Any ideas of what might be a likely culprit would be greatly appreciated!
creator: kharrisma

title: I know it's free and all, by why would TB be so dumb as to default to black on black for replies ?
content: How to make TB stop defaulting to black font color on black background for writing replies ? I've gotten so tired of undoing it choices, half the time I skip replying. Should just change email clients, might be easier in the long run.

title: Office 365 using two emails- one doesn't send.
content:
Greetings TB'ers. First time poster, pretty technical back ground. This problem is giving me fits. I purchased MS 365 email accounts through godaddy, and I like to use TB for all my emails which have yahoo, etc. They all work fine.

Now one of my MS365 emails sends and receives fine. The other will not send, but receives fine. When using MS's web client, it works fine. When using my ipad, it works fine. The issue seems to be some sort of TB setting. After trying for weeks to fix it myself, I finally gave up and called godaddy email support. We went through the exchange settings, server settings, and everything is set correctly. The working email has the identical settings as the non sending email (expect for the different email name of course). It is a mystery why one would work and not the other. The issue seems to be in the outgoing SMTP settings. I am using IMAP settings for both email addresses.

I have no clue how to get this going. I assume separate outgoing settings for each email is appropriate. Right? If not, then what email to I use?

Next Sec. Connection: Normal or Oauth2? The working email uses Normal.

When I make sever changes, do I need to restart TB? Or does it take affect immediately?

Any help would be very much appreciated.
creator: Squirmie

title: no longer able to send videos or pictures. Times out before it can send. Even typed e mails are sent very very slowly.

title: Thunderbird downloading gmail emails again
content:
A problem has arisen with Thunderbird. There are solutions for problems like this, but none quite like mine or current. I have Windows 10 64 bit OS, x64-based processor and Thunderbird 32 bit 102.10.1. I do not know why 32 bit Thunderbird is installed; 64 bit seems more apt.

I have run check disk, bad sectors marked on the C: SSD, which has a 99 per cent health reading on Crystal Info. Data is on an external drive, also good with no percentage cited.

There are two active email addresses on Thunderbird, both IMAP. The one that is not Gmail works fine. Gmail does not work well. Occasionally headers are downloaded, which does not matter much. The main problem is that Gmail emails vanish from Thunderbird, causing them to be downloaded again, much data volume. This has happened several times.

There's a folder C:\Users\Owner\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\tb.default\ImapMail\imap.gmail-1.com\Painting.sbd that seems to hold the painting emails. There's another folder C:\Users\Owner\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\tb.default\ImapMail\imap.gmail.com with painting.msf painting painting.sbd There are similar and identical folder names in TB for Gmail and non-Gmail, so the above three may refer to the non-Gmail folders. The ~\imap.gmail.com folder (the second one above) does not have many folders with the TB folder names.

One solution may be to delete all the ~imap.gmail-1.com\*.* folders and download the emails again. I'm unsure about this and advice is sought. Thanks.
creator: Anshe

title: Mysterious "nsmail-1.docx" files appear when I try to attach a Word file to an email.
content: I needed to add a Word document as an attachment to an email. While in the email, I clicked "Attach." The screen with Word docs opened. I clicked the filename I wanted to attach. It attached to the email. However, the attachment no longer had the original name I'd given it. Instead it was named "nsmail-1.docx, then nsmail-2.docx, then nsmail-3.docx, etc. When I clicked on this mysterious file, it was in fact my correct document. Why did this happen and how can I prevent it from happening again?"
creator: marywithaquestion

creator: Warren31

title: UI suggestion: Prevent Thunderbird from executing multiple commands at once
content:
Dear Thunderbird team,

yesterday I had a somewhat scary moment: I issued the "Archive" command by pressing "A" to archive all my mails from the Inbox, which took about 1-2 minutes. So far, so good. During this process, I changed the sound volume of my Mac using the keyboard buttons, which are right above the Backspace key. So I wasn't precise enough and hit the Backspace key while Thunderbird was archiving. That was a bad idea, because Thunderbird then started to delete all selected messages at the same time as it was archiving them! I was able to recover some e-mail from the Trash afterwards.

So I'd suggest that Thunderbird only allow one command to be executed at a time, lest they interfere with each other. Otherwise, I love Thunderbird.

Thanks for looking into this, regards,

Arthur
creator: anacond23
